posts.com:
Maybe look for a therapist. Their job is to listen, help you, and believe you. I have been in therapy for years, and it has helped me a lot. I always recommend it to people. Fuck stigmas, and society's 1950s mental health norm bullshit!

I know this forum probably hates it, but check out the resources with the me too movement. Find a group local to you, and start going to it. You need to find connection with people who have experienced your same struggles.

https://metoomvmt.org/explore-healing/resource-library/

I know as a young person things can seem really hopeless and pointless, but it gets better. You will grow as a person and have more empathy for others. Killing yourself is short sighted. This life is short enough, why make it any shorter.

Also, parents many times have our best interests at heart, HOWEVER, they don't always understand the situation to level or the degree of what is going on. You know yourself and the situation you are in! Trust yourself and go get help!

A long time ago I went on a date with a girl. We saw a movie. During the movie, she started rubbing my leg so I reciprocated and unfortunately, got a bit carried away and tried to take things further. She wasn’t having it so I respectfully stopped. Not my best idea.

We never really talked again after the date although she insisted that I kiss her goodbye. So we did make out some.

Fast forward roughly three years:

Last night, I was out at a cocktail bar when I think the previously mentioned girl walks into the bar. I’m pretty drunk, but 99% recognize her. We lock eyes for what seems like forever and she SHOULDER CHECKS me pretty hard as she walks by. Like a guy would do to another guy he’s trying to start a fight with, except she’s so little she just kinda bounces off me. I’m taken aback and find it slightly confusing.

Later in the night, I’m outside with a different friend when the girl walks by. I say her name out loud as she walks by and she completely ignores me.

Can anyone help me understand this situation? Did she recognize me when she first came into the bar, or not? I’m 99% sure it was the same girl.

The shoulder check didn’t scare me off at all as I’m much larger, but I’m wondering if it was her way of communicating she’s still upset about the awkward date? Can anyone perhaps elaborate?


Pic isn’t her but similar

Ever since I was young I've been scared of rejection and being mocked for trying. To give some examples, I don't talk to anyone and haven't had friends since I was a kid, because by me approaching someone, I'm making myself vulnerable by wanting to be liked and susceptible to mockery, whereas if I stay alone, I don't have to worry about any of that; I don't dress up nice since if I did, if anyone called me ugly it'd hurt but by not trying at all I can just shrug it off as 'well, I didn't put any effort in anyway'.

I know that I'm a coward, but being like this is far from a nightmare. When I was younger, I did want friends, to look good and to be 'normal', but that's since turned to numbness; I enjoy my own company and fare fine on my own, but I worry that when I'm older, that I'll regret choosing to be a bit of an outcast loser rather than try to fit in despite being a 'tard, even if none of that stuff really appeals to me anymore and just leaves a bad taste in my mouth from my own bitterness. At this point, I lean more towards staying the way I am, but that nagging feeling that I'm wasting my opportunities compelled me to make this thread.

I don't have any mental health issues or disorders, I think being humiliated by my parents most days just did a number on my mindset and being mocked feels like a fate worse than death.

Anon very few physicists believe dark matter or dark energy are ACTUALLY a thing.
Everyone pretty much agrees that our current theory for gravity has many flaws, BUT it's objectively the best anyone has ever come up with. posts.sub: How do I stop this before it happens?
posts.com: I have managed to stay away from online discourse and internet politics/drama for a short but decent bit of time now, and am already a lot happier as a whole. But tonight I overheard some stuff from my family that relates to some political stuff going on, and later I looked into it a bit, and eventually ended up stumbling partially down another online rabbit hole before I realized what I was doing and stopping myself before I got too worked up over stupid shit. The problem is, I have no idea if I’ll get mad or anxious over the little amount of stuff that I’ve already seen when I’m thinking about it later. I tend to ruminate a lot and have semi-intrusive thoughts about stuff that worries or irritates me, and I’m worried I’ll start spiraling into a mental funk again. I JUST got truly better and was happy for the first time in forever, I don’t wanna get sucked back into that headspace. I may be able to put it out of my mind, but I don’t know what I’ll do if my brain decides that I can’t just forget it. This is all kind of hard to communicate in terms of what my problem is, and the problem itself is inherently internal and mostly irrelevant, but I don’t know what else to do if I can’t put it all out of my mind. I just don’t wanna go back to being like that again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28268101
Firstly, congratulations on identifying what ruined your mood and cutting it out. That's no small feat, be proud of yourself. However, this is unfortunately not a one-and-done deal. Your brain likes familiarity, even if you suffer from it, and hates change due to evolutionarily reason. Meaning that you'll be prone to falling back into familiar patterns. This doesn't mean you're a hopeless case, though. Every time it happens, you'll notice it more quickly and thus can pull the breaks more quickly, too. I get that you're worried, you probably thought once you identified the problem and got rid of it you'd be opening a new chapter. And in a way, you absolutely have! But behaviour we've shown for years, and thought patterns that are familiar to us, aren't easy to unlearn.
Be kind to yourself. This doesn't mean you've failed. It means you're in the slow process of succeeding. You're worrying about being stuck in this rut forever because you're prone to worrying, not because there is any truth to it. The brain is a tricky, clever beast. Be kind to yourself, don't chide yourself for falling back into familiar patterns. Recognise it, acknowledge it, then do what you can to break out. Again, and again, and again. At some point, your brain will get the message. One thing to keep in mind that helped me just by being aware of it: you are not your thoughts, you are the observer of your thoughts. So observe them, acknowledge them, then deal with what is causing them.
This might sound cheesy but as long as you don't let fallbacks discourage you from another attempt at change, you will be fine and get there eventually.

5'11" 160ish nigga here I got down to 120 during the chinavirus by autistically counting calories and measuring portions, eating 2 meals per day adding up to about 1000kcal. Luckily I was a neet in those days, towards the end I was so tired that I could scarcely get out of bed and eating was the only thing I had to look forward to. Keep in mind that nutritional facts labels are based on the absolute amount of chemical energy contained in food, while the human metabolism can only unlock a certain percentage of it. So say you eat a can of tuna with 100 calories you're probably getting like 70 or 80. Carbs are processed more efficiently than protein. You can eat more than you think and still lose weight as long as you avoid bread, fruit and things like that

I always want to do productive things like workout out regularly, learn cool shit and engage in more fulfilling hobbies. But I end up wasting most of my time in mindnumbing shit like watching Youtube videos, consuming meaningless sports and other medias, and responding to strangers on imageboards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28267817

Schedule your time. Even if you don't start by doing hour by hour breakdowns, program yourself to think "I have to XYZ Tuesday and thursday" or "I have to read 10 pages of the book I'm working on before I go to sleep." Start with small, easily completable goals and build on successes as you go.

It's better to do 5 push-ups and say "I did something" than to do nothing and lament that you didn't go crush plates in the gym for an hour.

>>28267703
Social darwinism is what most people believe unless you tell them to believe otherwise (eg about racial, or other categories).
It essentially says "the weakest should suffer and die alone for the betterment of the species". This is what happens naturally; social darwinists say "it's a good thing".

I (and other people opposed to this) say it's a bad thing, that all humans are valuable. Maybe you've heard of Moravec's Paradox: people who don't realize how valuable and cool a human is have never tried to replicate what one can do. Take a class on AI or learn to code and you will see how amazing a human's abilities are. A human is a great thing and so is a consciousness, and people should have love and happiness and we should do what it takes to make that possible.

Others disagree, say "the weakest should be culled". But they don't believe this as an ideology of eugenics, they are simply expressing what they feel is their high social status: "I am better than them, I should be happy, they should suffer". That's what I disagree with. And always will. But the world belongs to them, so we and all others have to try our best to navigate the world they have created, of conflict, competition, dominance, and hate.

>>28267115
>How do I deal with anxiety?
If it's actually real (e.g. sleep, diet, being attacked at home) then fix your IRL situation
If it's a hallucination (I.e. care too much about how other people see you) then literally stop, because feelings are a choice, and you can use reality to remind you to not feel dumb shit.
(You can choose to override the actual real problems too, but in that case reality is not on your side so it's a LOT harder)
>Recently a secret of mine has been revealed and I'm a bit ashamed of it and embarrassed
Anxiety is completely normal. It's reminding you to prepare for an attack so you can counterattack or evade.
>this girl knows and I just don't know what to do.
Create rough plans and be ready for what happens if you get confronted. Isn't that what anxiety is telling you to do?
>This could potentially ruin my social life at work where they are.
That, however, is not part of reality. Bitches talk shit, and the counter to bitches talking shit is to inform people "Nah, bitch is talking shit". Or you can get a different social network. Or just be alone for a bit, because you don't need social approval to be worth hiring.
There are many solutions to that, so your fear is not part of reality. Have less fear.
>Why do people do this?
I honestly don't think about that so I can't say. Besides, it's not your concern either, since you don't control her and so that knowledge wouldn't affect anything.
Worry instead about how you can react to people being dipshits, because that is a productive line of reasoning.
>she's doing it just to harm me for fun because I was too nice in sharing my personal details about my life, and here she is just taking advantage maliciously.
Probably yeah. So? If she's that much of a cunt, let her set her own deathtrap and out herself as a bitch to others, problem solved.

>went on several long walks

>>28266232
The point is that most people don't have a plan, or already do and are procrastinating. People need to act, and not plan so much they miss the window. Most plans for most things take maybe five minutes to come up with. If you can't improvise past initial engagement, then you need to re-train. Plans are the folly of man.

So rigid are our plans that they break upon the first unseen obstacle. Nothing can see everything in this world, and so you must account for the unexpected. It is better to conceptualize your goal, your approach, and account for possible obstacles. Don't detail you negotiation; you will get hung up on it.

If you see the window, send it. In your time waiting, you should've been working on footwork instead of memorizing every punch. You'll not get anywhere if you're quaking in your boots. Simply do it, and it will come to you as you go. Open yourself up to flow, and run with it.

I can almost guarantee you that whatever you're planning for doesn't require going through METTC or the MDMP; you're likely planning a workout routine, a work schedule, or maybe even some middle-management logistics. You're likely not raiding Fort Knox, let alone coordinating a counter-offensive with combined arms.

Just quit overthinking it, and do it. Worst they'll tell you is no.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Look at you blaming your parents for your own misfortune. Here's the thing: nobody had perfect parents. We were all neglected or even abused in some way. What's important is you acknowledge this, try your best to fix the imperfections cast upon you, and be grateful for the things your parents did right. I was raised by a single mom who yelled and even hit me when she was strung out from dealing with a petulant child (me) at the end of the day after working her graveyard shift at the hospital. Do I hold this against her? No. She's just a human being. To this day she sometimes tells me she's sorry for what she did and I always tell her I love her regardless.

Anyways: 28 is still pretty young, but you need to stop fucking around. You need to really, *really* think about what you want in life. Take a sabbatical from your every day habits and use this time to hunker down and figure this out. Then -- this is important -- once you figure out a way to orient yourself you TAKE ACTION. Don't worry about if it's the wrong thing or not, because you can always reorient yourself in the future. Keep trying new stuff out and see what sticks. Pay close attention to how you receive information regarding this new material. Are you immersed and satisfied, or does it not quite match your tastes? If you want a job that doesn't make you miserable in life, then you have to be keenly aware of these things.

Good luck, man.
